Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Reduction of Melt Pool Balling in Metal Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant will explore the feasibility of using alloy metal powder for additive manufacturing. Additive manufacturing is changing how metal parts are built. The work in this research focuses on a particular additive manufacturing process where a laser beam traces a part shape over a layer of metal powder. The powder under the beam melts and solidifies as the laser moves away. When the trace is finished, new powder is spread and the trace repeated. Eventually a solid part is built. To build usable parts, the traces should be flat, continuous layers. This is determined by the power of the laser beam and the speed at which it travels. At the high values of power and speed, the melted material solidifies as a series of droplets instead of a continuous layer. This is called balling and it leads to unusable parts that are not completely solid. Balling limits how fast usable parts can be built because building is faster at high power and speed. Surprisingly, most metal powder compositions for additive manufacturing are based on those commonly used in subtractive manufacturing processes (e.g. cutting or milling) and are not optimized for additive applications. The team will tackle this problem by exploring the feasibility of controlling balling by adding alloying elements to the powders that change the behavior of the molten metal, and by demonstrating a new, cost effective method to evaluate different alloy compositions. Both research components of this EAGER award have the potential to make significant improvements in the speed and cost effectiveness of powder customization for additive manufacturing and component fabrication.


The research work will investigate the balling defect in selective laser melting additive manufacturing and the effect of surface active elements. The reduction in surface energy with addition of surface active elements is expected to lead to reduce balling, since it has been associated with Plateau-Rayleigh instabilities and poor wettability. As sulfur lowers surface tension and strongly influences melt pool shape in laser welding, this research will investigate the effect of sulfur alloying content on stainless steel alloy melt pools. To overcome the prohibitively high costs associated with the fabrication of small batches of customized alloy metal powders for research purposes, this EAGER award will evaluate the suitability of testing on solid test samples. Solid test samples will be fabricated by arc-melting and machining processes. Initially the bulk material composition of the solid samples will be the same as commercial metal additive powders. Tracks of laser re-melted material will be made on these samples over a range of beam power and travel speeds with a focus on power and speed combinations where the transition to balling is expected. Tests will also be conducted with different powder layer thicknesses on the samples, and then on samples with varying sulfur content. Melt pool shapes and microstructures will be characterized and compared. The potential contributions of this work are validation of a cost-effective test method to evaluate alloy composition for selective laser melting additive manufacturing using solid samples, and a demonstration of process-related defect reduction through adjustments to alloy composition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the additive manufacturing process Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF), a laser is rapidly scanned over a bed of metal powder, building parts in a layer-by-layer fashion. The laser heat source produces small melt pools, when enables parts to be built with good spatial resolution. Many defects can arise depending on the process parameters (beam power, travel speed, width between passes, scanning strategy) and part geometry.  Initial exploration of possible combinations of process parameters begins with single-bead experiments where a single melt track is created by the laser. These experiments can be done with or without the presence of powder and can be used to efficiently study the melt pool geometry and microstructure over a wide range of process variables. Single-bead tests can identify combinations of process variables where undesirable melt pool features are observed: (1) keyholing, where deep vapor cavities lead to porosity, (2) lack-of-fusion, narrow and shallow melt pools, and (3) balling, where the width and height of remelted material fluctuate along the track length.  Keyholing and lack-of-fusion have been widely studied and while balling is often mentioned, its fundamental basis is not yet understood. 

This work explored the factors that affect the balling phenomenon in L-PBF using single-bead tests and methods of studying the phenomenon in-situ. The balling phenomenon occurs at high laser powers and velocities and leads to melt pool cross sections as illustrated in Figure 1. Balling leads to height variations along the melt pool track length and can potentially be a source of porosity and poor surface finish.  Since balling occurs at high combinations of power and travel speed, it limits the build rate of L-BPF. Balling is typically attributed to the Plateau-Rayleigh instability, where a column of fluid breaks up into droplets if its length-to-width ratio exceeds pi. Balling is also likely affected by fluid flow in the melt pool and the local solidification rate in the melt pool.

In this work, single-bead tests were used to study effects of surface-active elements, substrate surface finish, and the presence of powder on balling. While surface active elements such as sulfur have been shown to alter the fluid flow inside the melt pools of welds, no differences in balling behavior were observed for two 304 stainless steel samples with sulfur contents, 20 ppm and 200ppm. Substrate surface roughness did affect balling, with machined, ground, and polished surfaces tested. Rougher substrate surface finishes led to balling at lower values of power and velocity. The presence of powder also led to balling at lower values of power and velocity. The results of these experiments testing the influence of certain factors on the balling phenomenon were compared against analytical model predictions of the melt pool length to melt pool width ratios. It was found that the Plateau-Rayleigh criterion (and a modified one proposed for L-BPF) were not predictive, i.e., balling occurred at power and velocity combinations above and below the criteria.

Single-bead experiments were also performed at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Lab to study the phenomenon in-situ. The preliminary high speed x-ray imaging offers a side view of melt pools and show that vapor cavities were present at all process variables tested, though the vapor cavities were much shallower than those associated with keyholing. The formation of balled up regions of liquid metal could be also be observed. Synchronous infrared imaging was employed to observe temperatures at the top of the melt pool. The formation of balled regions was clear and consistent with x-ray imaging.  Initial analysis suggested  while observing vapor cavities and the formation of balled up regions from the side perspective with high-speed x-ray imaging. The results show infrared imaging can be used in-situ to identify the onset of balling. Overall, the project results indicated that a balling onset criterion based on melt pool shape did not appear sufficient to explain the observed results and that additional in-situ and ex-situ characterization is needed to be better define the onset of melt pool balling. Additionally, the project demonstrated an application of high speed, multimodal characterization methods to understanding the behavior of melt pools during L-PBF additive manufacturing.


Last Modified: 01/05/2021
Modified by: Bryan Webler
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In the additive manufacturing process Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF), a laser is rapidly scanned over a bed of metal powder, building parts in a layer-by-layer fashion. The laser heat source produces small melt pools, when enables parts to be built with good spatial resolution. Many defects can arise depending on the process parameters (beam power, travel speed, width between passes, scanning strategy) and part geometry. Initial exploration of possible combinations of process parameters begins with single-bead experiments where a single melt track is created by the laser. These experiments can be done with or without the presence of powder and can be used to efficiently study the melt pool geometry and microstructure over a wide range of process variables. Single-bead tests can identify combinations of process variables where undesirable melt pool features are observed: (1) keyholing, where deep vapor cavities lead to porosity, (2) lack-of-fusion, narrow and shallow melt pools, and (3) balling, where the width and height of remelted material fluctuate along the track length. This work explored the factors that affect the balling phenomenon in L-PBF using single-bead tests and methods of studying the phenomenon in-situ. The balling phenomenon occurs at high laser powers and velocities and leads to melt pool cross sections as illustrated in Figure 1. Since balling occurs at high combinations of power and travel speed, it limits the build rate of L-BPF. Balling is typically attributed to the Plateau-Rayleigh instability, where a column of fluid breaks up into droplets if its length-to-width ratio exceeds pi. In this work, single-bead tests were used to study effects of surface-active elements, substrate surface finish, and the presence of powder on balling. While surface active elements such as sulfur have been shown to alter the fluid flow inside the melt pools of welds, no differences in balling behavior were observed for two 304 stainless steel samples with sulfur contents, 20 ppm and 200ppm. Additionally, the project demonstrated an application of high speed, multimodal characterization methods to understanding the behavior of melt pools during L-PBF additive manufacturing.
